SubTopics: Identify and describe examples of common technological changes past to present in the community (e.g., energy production, transportation, communications, agriculture, packaging materials) that have either positive or negative impacts on society or the environment.
Content: Over the past hundred years, people have built new and better roads in Pennsylvania. What is one possible negative effect of this technology?

Key.Rationale: Decreased expense would be a positive effect, not a negative effect.

B.Choice: Traveling greater distances is more difficult.

Key.Rationale: New and better roads make traveling greater distances easier, not more difficult.

C.Choice: Wildlife habitats are separated into smaller areas.

Key.Rationale: Roads can separate wildlife habitats into smaller areas and negatively impact species that live in the areas.

D.Choice: Mail delivery services take longer to reach people.

Key.Rationale: New and better roads allow mail to be delivered more quickly, not more slowly.

SubTopics: Observe and record change by using time and measurement.
Content: Use the drawings below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/2a.jpg
Which change occurred between January 1 and May 1?

Key.Rationale: The time between sunrise and sunset increased between January 1 and May 1.
The drawings show times, not temperatures.

C.Choice: Earth rotated more quickly around its axis.

Key.Rationale: The speed of Earthâ€™s rotation does not change during the year.

D.Choice: Earth made one revolution around the Sun.

Key.Rationale: Earth makes one revolution around the Sun in one year, not in four months.

SubTopics: Observe and record change by using time and measurement.
Content: A student wants to measure the depth of each snowfall in January. Which tools are most helpful for gathering and recording the data?

Key.Rationale: Neither a shovel nor a calculator is a tool for measuring.
A beaker can be used to measure volume, but not length. A stopwatch can be used to measure time in seconds and minutes, but not days and months.
A balance can be used to measure mass. A computer is not a tool for measuring.

D.Choice: The meterstick will allow the student to record the depth of snow in centimeters, and the calendar will allow the student to record the day of the month.

SubTopics: Design and describe an investigation (a fair test) to test one variable.
Content: Use the drawing below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/4a.jpg
A student wants to compare how long a flashlight will continue to shine using different brands of batteries. How can the student make sure that the test is fair?

A.Choice: Test the same brand of batteries in two flashlights.

Key.Rationale: The student wants to compare different brands of batteries, not the same brand.

B.Choice: Test each brand of batteries in the same flashlight.

Key.Rationale: Using different brands of batteries in the same flashlight will limit the number of variables.

C.Choice: Test different sizes of batteries in the same flashlight.

Key.Rationale: Only one size of battery will work in the flashlight.

D.Choice: Test whether some flashlights can work with only one battery.

Key.Rationale: The student wants to compare different brands of batteries, not different flashlights.

SubTopics: Observe a natural phenomenon (e.g., weather changes, length of daylight/night, movement of shadows, animal migrations, growth of plants), record observations, and then make a prediction based on those observations.
Content: Use the table below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/5a.jpg
A student observes the first day merganser ducks arrive at a lake each year during their migration. When will the merganser ducks most likely arrive at the lake in year 5?

Key.Rationale: The earliest that merganser ducks have been observed is February 22, so it is unlikely that they will arrive before this date.
The earliest that merganser ducks have been observed is February 22, so it is unlikely that they will arrive before this date.
The merganser ducks were observed arriving between February 22 and March 10, so it is unlikely they will arrive as late as April.
The merganser ducks have been observed arriving at the lake between February 22 and March 10 in previous years, so they will most likely continue this pattern in future years.

SubTopics: Categorize systems as either natural or human-made (e.g., ballpoint pens, simple electrical circuits, plant anatomy, water cycle).
Content: Which system is partly natural and partly human-made?

A.Choice: a pen that writes in blue ink

Key.Rationale: Both the pen and ink are human-made.

B.Choice: a tree that produces edible fruit

Key.Rationale: Both the tree and fruit are natural.

C.Choice: a mountain that erodes over time

Key.Rationale: Both the mountain and the process of erosion are natural.

D.Choice: a coral reef that grows on old train cars

Key.Rationale: The coral reef is natural and the train cars are human-made.

SubTopics: Categorize systems as either natural or human-made (e.g., ballpoint pens, simple electrical circuits, plant anatomy, water cycle).
Content: A student described human-made systems and natural systems. Which characteristic was most likely used to describe both systems?

Key.Rationale: Human-made systems do not grow larger.
Human-made systems do not need oxygen.
Both human-made systems and natural systems have multiple parts.
Natural systems are not powered by electricity.

SubTopics: Explain a relationship between the living and nonliving components in a system (e.g., food web, terrarium).
Content: Use the drawing below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/8a.jpg
How does the soil help the plants in the terrarium?

A.Choice: The soil absorbs sunlight for the plants.

Key.Rationale: Plants absorb sunlight to grow. They do not get sunlight from the soil.

B.Choice: The soil produces energy for the plants.

Key.Rationale: Plants make their own energy from sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide. They do not get energy from the soil.

C.Choice: The soil provides the plants with a place to grow.

Key.Rationale: Plants grow in soil.

D.Choice: The soil protects the plants from other organisms.

Key.Rationale: The soil does not protect the plants from other organisms.

SubTopics: Describe how different parts of a living thing work together to provide what the organism needs (e.g., parts of plants: roots, stems, leaves).
Content: How do the human nose and lungs work together?

A.Choice: The nose filters air that is processed in the lungs.

Key.Rationale: Air is inhaled through the nose, filtered, and then processed in the lungs.

B.Choice: The nose brings in food that is digested in the lungs.

Key.Rationale: The nose and lungs are part of the respiratory system, not the digestive system.

C.Choice: The nose lets out energy that is produced by the lungs.

Key.Rationale: The nose filters air that is processed in the lungs. The nose does not let out energy that is produced by the lungs.

D.Choice: The nose senses odors that are understood by the lungs.

Key.Rationale: The nose has sensors that receive information about smells, but this information is processed by the brain, not the lungs.

SubTopics: Identify physical characteristics (e.g., height, hair color, eye color, attached earlobes, ability to roll tongue) that appear in both parents and could be passed on to offspring.
Content: Use the lists below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/10a.jpg
How are these lists of traits different?

A.Choice: Only the traits in List A can change.

Key.Rationale: The traits in both lists can change over time.

B.Choice: Only the traits in List B are formed naturally.

Key.Rationale: The traits in both lists can be formed naturally.

C.Choice: Only the traits in List A are inherited from parents.

Key.Rationale: The traits in List A are controlled by genes passed on from the parents.

D.Choice: Only the traits in List B can affect a personâ€™s survival.

Key.Rationale: The traits in List B would be unlikely to affect a personâ€™s survival.

SubTopics: Explain and predict how changes in seasons affect plants, animals, or daily human life (e.g., food availability, shelter, mobility).
Content: Use the graph below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/11a.jpg
Plants and animals respond to changes in their natural environment. Which natural response can most likely be predicted due to the changing amounts of daylight shown in the graph?

A.Choice: Birds will migrate north between July and December.

Key.Rationale: Birds migrate south, not north, between July and December.

B.Choice: Birds will migrate south between January and March.

Key.Rationale: Birds migrate north, not south, between January and March.

C.Choice: Plants will absorb the most energy between May and July.

Key.Rationale: The numbers of hours of daylight are greatest between May and July, allowing plants to absorb the most energy during this time.

D.Choice: Plants will absorb the most energy between March and May.

Key.Rationale: The numbers of hours of daylight are greatest between May and July, not between March and May.

SubTopics: Describe the flow of energy through an object or system (e.g., feeling radiant heat from a light bulb, eating food to get energy, using a battery to light a bulb or run a fan).
Content: A log burns in a fireplace. Nearby, a light bulb is glowing. How are the fire and the light bulb alike?

Key.Rationale: Energy is not created by either the fire or the light bulb.
Both sources release light energy. They do not absorb it.
The fire and the light bulb both release energy in the form of light.
The fire does not use electrical energy.

SubTopics: Recognize or illustrate simple direct current series and parallel circuits composed of batteries, light bulbs (or other common loads), wire, and on/off switches.
Content: Use the drawing below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/13a.jpg
A schoolyard playground reminded a student of an electrical circuit. Which type of circuit would the student most likely describe using the playground?

A.Choice: a series circuit because there is only one way up to the top

Key.Rationale: The circuit is parallel, not series, because there is more than one path to the ground.

B.Choice: a series circuit because the students can only go down the slides

Key.Rationale: The circuit is parallel, not series, because there is more than one path to the ground.

C.Choice: a parallel circuit because the students change directions as they are playing

Key.Rationale: The arrows do not indicate that the students can change direction while playing.

D.Choice: a parallel circuit because students have two ways to slide down to the ground

Key.Rationale: Parallel circuits have more than one path for the current to flow; the two slides show this split.

SubTopics: Compare the relative movement of objects or describe types of motion that are evident (e.g., bouncing ball, moving in a straight line, back and forth, merry-go-round).
Content: Use the drawing below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/14a.jpg
Which statement best describes the movement of the student and the ball in the drawing?

A.Choice: The student is only moving from side to side, while the basketball is only moving up and down.

Key.Rationale: The basketball is also moving from side to side, not just up and down.

B.Choice: The student is mostly moving up and down, while the basketball is mostly moving from side to side.

Key.Rationale: The student is moving from side to side, not up and down. Also, the basketball is moving up and down and from side to side.

C.Choice: The student is only moving up and down, while the basketball is moving up and down and from side to side.

Key.Rationale: The student is moving from side to side, not up and down.

D.Choice: The student is mostly moving from side to side, while the basketball is moving from side to side and up and down.

Key.Rationale: The student is moving from side to side, and the basketball is moving both up and down and from side to side.

SubTopics: Describe types of freshwater and saltwater bodies (e.g., lakes, rivers, wetlands, oceans).
Content: A student lives near a lake. Which observation is the student most likely to make about the lake?

A.Choice: The water is fresh rather than salty.

Key.Rationale: Most lakes contain fresh water.

B.Choice: The lake empties into a larger body of water.

Key.Rationale: Rivers, not lakes, empty into larger bodies of water.

C.Choice: The water flows quickly from high to low areas.

Key.Rationale: Lakes contain still water. They do not flow.

D.Choice: The lake completely dries up during some seasons.

Key.Rationale: Lakes are usually too large to completely dry up.

SubTopics: Identify weather patterns from data charts or graphs of the data (e.g., temperature, wind direction, wind speed, cloud types, precipitation).
Content: Use the weather map below to answer the question.
problems/PA18G4S/media/16a.jpg
Which type of front is likely to arrive soon in Philadelphia?

Key.Rationale: There is no cold front to the north of Philadelphia.
There is no cold front to the south of Philadelphia.
There is no warm front to the north of Philadelphia.
There is a warm front to the south of Philadelphia, and it will most likely move northeast and affect Philadelphia.
